p.text: The Court shall administer concurrently all rules of law, including rules of equity.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 57.5] Concurrent administration of equity and common law

heading.title: Concurrent administration of equity and common law

p.text: The concurrent administration of law and equity directed under this Part is not a fusion of the two systems, but rather of the courts which previously severally administered those systems: O'Rourke v Hoeven [1974] 1 NSWLR 622 at 626; R Meagher, D Heydon and M Leeming Meagher, Gummow and Lehane's Equity Doctrines and Remedies 4th ed, LexisNexis Butterworths, Sydney, 2002 at [2–100]. As a consequence of this limitation, the section does not extend the equitable doctrine of part performance to common law claims: Britain v Rossiter (1879) 11 QBD 123 ; JC Williamson Ltd v Lukey (1931) 45 CLR 282; 37 ALR 157 ; O'Rourke v Hoeven [1974] 1 NSWLR 622 .

Where a plaintiff claims to be entitled to any equitable estate or right or to relief upon any equitable ground against any deed, instrument or contract, or against any right, title or claim whatsoever asserted by any defendant in the proceedings, or to any relief founded upon a legal right which formerly could only have been given by a court of equity, the Court shall give to the plaintiff the same relief as ought formerly to have been given by a court of equity in proceedings for the like purpose.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 58.5] Procedural merger of equity and common law

heading.title: Procedural merger of equity and common law

p.text: This Act merges the administration of law and equity but does not alter the rights of the parties or enable remedies to be given where they previously could not be given. The equitable jurisdiction of the court used to be considered under three heads, viz: (1) exclusive, where the right to be enforced and the remedy to enforce it were both equitable; (2) concurrent, where the right was legal but the remedy equitable; and (3) auxiliary, where the right and remedy were both legal and equity only intervened to assist the common law court. The third category was in effect abolished by this Act. If an equitable remedy is sought for the breach of a legal right the existence of the right, and the breach, must first be ascertained in accordance with the law: Colls v Home & Colonial Stores Ltd [1904] AC 179 .

Where a defendant claims to be entitled to any equitable estate or right, or to relief upon any equitable ground against any deed, instrument or contract or against any right, title or claim asserted by any plaintiff in the proceedings, or alleges any ground of equitable defence to any claim of the plaintiff, the Court shall give to every equitable estate, right or ground of relief so claimed, and every equitable defence so alleged, the same effect by way of defence against the claim of the plaintiff as a court of equity ought formerly to have given if the like matters had been relied on by way of defence in any proceedings instituted for the like purpose.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 59.5] Merger of equitable and legal defences

heading.title: Merger of equitable and legal defences

p.text: The effect of this section is that an equitable defence has the same effect as it would have had in separate equity proceedings before the commencement of the Supreme Court Act. Equitable defences are to be pleaded in the main proceedings, and not made the subject of separate claims in equity: Garbutt v Fawcus (1875) 1 Ch D 155 . Illustrations include Bankes v Jarvis [1903] 1 KB 549 where a trustee pleaded in defence to an action for debt that the beneficiary was liable in unliquidated damages to the defendant; Mostyn v West Mostyn Coal Co (1876) 1 CPD 145 where the defendant claimed to set aside the lease as a defence to an action for rent. See also Marshall v Marshall (1879) 5 CPD 19; Eyre v Hughes (1876) 2 Ch D 148; Thellusson v Liddard [1900] 2 Ch 635 at 646; and Attorney-General for Trinidad v Bourne [1895] AC 83 . However the scope of the equitable defence is not enlarged. This limitation is illustrated by the proposition that the defence of accord and satisfaction is only good against a creditor plaintiff who was actually a party to the accord: Steeds v Steeds (1889) 22 QBD 537 at 541 (equity presumes co-creditors are interested as tenants in common rather than joint tenants). unless the claimant creditor’s joint interest is established (for example by admission): Powell v Brodhurst [1901] 2 Ch 164.

The Court shall recognise and take notice of all equitable estates, titles and rights, and all equitable duties and liabilities appearing incidentally in the course of any proceedings, in the manner in which a court of equity would have recognised and taken notice of those matters in any proceedings instituted therein.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 61] s 61 Defence or stay instead of injunction

leg:heading.title: Defence or stay instead of injunction

p.text: The Court shall not restrain by injunction any proceedings pending in the Court.
[subs (1) subst Act 41 of 1972 s 6]

Every matter of equity on which an injunction against the prosecution of proceedings in the Court might formerly have been obtained, whether on terms or conditions or not, may be relied on by way of defence in the proceedings.
Where any person, whether a party to proceedings in the Court or not—
would formerly have been entitled to apply to the Court to restrain the prosecution of the proceedings; or
is entitled to enforce by attachment or otherwise any judgment or order in contravention of which the proceedings are taken,
the Court may, on application by the person stay the proceedings either generally or to such extent as the Court thinks fit.
[subs (3) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
This section does not affect the powers of the Court to stay proceedings otherwise than pursuant to this section.

Prior to the introduction of the Judicature Act of 1873, actions could only be stayed by injunction. Such an injunction could be issued to prevent litigation which was considered either unnecessary in the sense of being vexatious or otherwise ill adapted to secure complete justice between the parties: Carron Iron Co v MacLaren (1885) 5 HL Cas 416; 10 ER 961. Section 24(5) of the Supreme Court of Judicature Act (1873), which is the precursor of the present section, removed the power to restrain proceedings by an injunction and expressly provided that it did not prevent the court from staying any proceedings “if it shall think fit”: see generally MacShannon v Rockware Glass Ltd [1978] AC 795; [1978] 1 All ER 625 and see the notes to s 67 of the CPA at [s 67.15]–[s 67.70] . The terms of the section are absolute and without any exception: Wright v Redgrave (1879) 11 Ch D 24 at 34 . The method of dealing with this sort of question is now either for the court to grant a stay or else give a direction to the appropriate officer of the court: Re Maidstone Palace of Varieties: Blair v Maidstone Palace of Varieties [1909] 2 Ch 283 at 286.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 61.10] Injunction to restrain the commencement of proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 61.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 section.

heading.title: Injunction to restrain the commencement of proceedings

p.text: The section only applies to proceedings pending in the court, thus it does not prevent a court from restraining a person from instituting proceedings such as a presentation of a petition to wind up a company: Cercle Restaurant Castiglione Co v Lavery (1881) 18 Ch D 555 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 61.15] Inherent power to stay proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 61.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 61(4).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 67.

Section 61(4) recognises the inherent power of the court to stay. The powers of the court generally to stay are examined in the notes to s 67 of the CPA, and see Aravas v Metropolitan Water Sewerage and Drainage Board (1970) 72 SR (NSW) 596 at 603 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 62] s 62 Common law and statutory rights and duties

leg:heading.title: Common law and statutory rights and duties

p.text: Subject to the provisions of this Act for giving effect to equitable rights and other matters of equity, and subject to section 5 of the Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act, 1972, the Court shall give effect to all legal claims and demands and all estates, titles, rights, duties, obligations and liabilities existing by the common law or by any custom, or created by any statute.

The Court shall grant, either absolutely or on terms, all such remedies as any party may appear to be entitled to in respect of any legal or equitable claim brought forward in the proceedings so that, as far as possible, all matters in controversy between the parties may be completely and finally determined, and all multiplicity of legal proceedings concerning any of those matters avoided.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 63.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.1.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 22 , 90.

This section expresses the fundamental principle of avoiding multiplicity of proceedings. See Manchester Sheffield & Lincolnshire Railway Co v Brooks (1877) 2 Ex D 243 at 246–7; McGowan v Middleton (1883) 11 QBD 464 at 468 ; Searle v Choat (1884) 25 Ch D 723 at 727 . The importance of adhering to this principle was emphasised by the High Court in Neeta (Epping) Pty Ltd v Phillips (1974) 131 CLR 286; 3 ALR 151 and by the Court of Appeal in Marra Developments Ltd v BW Rofe Pty Ltd [1977] 2 NSWLR 616 ; Coles v Wood [1981] 1 NSWLR 723 and Lohar Corp Pty Ltd v Dibu Pty Ltd [1976] ACLD 426; (1976) 1 BPR 9177 .

The section permits the court to grant any relief to which a party may be entitled even though no specific claim has been formally made in the proceedings: see r 36.1 of the UCPR and ss 22 and 90 of the CPA. However, if any affirmative claim is to be advanced, either by a plaintiff or a defendant, it is highly desirable that the party should be required to formulate the claim precisely: Dunne v Elibank-Murray (1982) NSW Conv R 55–057.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 63.10] Desirability of findings and determination on all issues

heading.title: Desirability of findings and determination on all issues

p.text: Consistently with the requirements of the section, it is desirable that a trial judge formally determine and make findings on all issues litigated in the proceedings. In particular they should make findings on the question of damages even where they determine the question of liability in favour of the defendant: Lawrence v Nominal Defendant (NSW) (1984) 1 MVR 388 . However this general rule does not affect the court's power to order the determination of separate questions. Where this occurs and, for example, a plaintiff fails on liability, the trial judge is not required to proceed with a further separate hearing on the question of damages: Di Pietro v Hamilton (NSWCA, Full Court, 6 September 1990, unreported, BC9002048).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 63.15] Determination of all issues — exception — winding up proceedings

heading.title: Determination of all issues — exception — winding up proceedings

p.text: It is ordinarily not appropriate for a winding up claim to be joined with other claims for relief: Permanent Custodians Ltd v Digital Enterprises Pty Ltd (1992) 8 ACSR 542 .

“In accordance with the principle embodied in the section the discretion to grant declaratory relief should only be exercised where the declaration sought will have a practical utility in the circumstances. The jurisdiction should not be exercised to decide matters which are hypothetical or those where the claimant has no real interest in the subject matter of the declaration. Moreover, the presence of an element of public interest cannot make good the absence of the requisite personal interest”: McGarrigle v Public Service Board [1979] 1 NSWLR 292. See also Ainsworth v Criminal Justice Commission (1992) 175 CLR 564 at 582; 106 ALR 11 . Where substantive remedies can be sought it has been said that the court should insist on their being added to the claim for a declaration and that the court should in an appropriate case refuse to entertain proceedings for declarations unless the relevant substantive remedies are claimed in addition: Coles v Wood [1981] 1 NSWLR 723. Thus unless the parties are agreed upon the consequences, a declaration that a contract for the sale of land has not been rescinded should not be granted without orders for consequential relief, since this does not achieve the purpose of the section: Neeta (Epping) Pty Ltd v Phillips (1974) 131 CLR 286; 3 ALR 151 . See also Trans Realties Pty Ltd v Grbac [1975] 1 NSWLR 170. Since these decisions the judges in the Equity Division have usually made such declarations but then adjourned the proceedings and reserved costs until the proceedings were in such a form to enable all questions between the parties to be dealt with: see Winchcombe Carson Trustee Co Ltd v Ball-Rand Pty Ltd [1974] 1 NSWLR 477 and Trans Realties Pty Ltd v Grbac, at 182, 185 but cf Australian Softwood Forests Pty Ltd v A-G (NSW); Ex rel Corporate Affairs Commission (1981) 148 CLR 121 at 125; 36 ALR 257 at 258 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 63.25] Construction issues in probate related proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 63.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Succession Act 2006 Ch 3.

heading.title: Construction issues in probate related proceedings

p.text: If all proper persons are parties and it is expedient, questions of construction of a will may be dealt with in proceedings under the Succession Act 2006 Ch 3 : Estate of Langley (dec'd); Langley v Langley [1974] 1 NSWLR 46.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 63.30] Circuity of action as a defence

heading.title: Circuity of action as a defence

p.text: The section affects resort to the defence of circuity of action. See Aktieselskabet Ocean Ltd v B Harding & Sons Ltd [1928] 2 KB 371 at 391. As to the former position see Imperial Furniture Pty Ltd v Automatic Fire Sprinklers Pty Ltd [1967] 1 NSWR 29.

This provision will support a cross-claim by a plaintiff, in reply to a defence or cross-claim by a defendant, when amendment by the plaintiff would be impossible and injustice would otherwise be done: see Renton Gibbs & Co Ltd v Neville & Co [1900] 2 QB 181; Bankes v Jarvis [1903] 1 KB 549.
[s 64 rep Act 28 of 1972 s 3(2)]

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 64.5] Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 64.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972.

This section was re-enacted by the Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972 so as to apply to all courts. That Act with annotations is reproduced behind guide card “Other Legislation” in Vol 3. The reason for this change was that although the section was derived from the well known s 25(11) of the Judicature Act 1873 to provide that if there was any conflict between the rules of equity and common law the former would prevail, the section lacked the clear introductory manner of the English provision and needed to be put in separate legislation to make it clear that it applied to all matters in New South Wales and not merely to proceedings in the Supreme Court. See R Meagher, D Heydon and M Leeming Meagher, Gummow and Lehane's Equity Doctrines and Remedies 4th ed, LexisNexis Butterworths, Sydney, 2002 at [2–080].
